Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2007 07:56PM Bendcoles wrote: I am feeling the exact same way too! I finish rads on my left breast this Friday and then I see my GYN Monday to talk about whether or not I need a hysterectomy. Then in Dec I have a follow up mammogram and MRI because I have 2 cysts in my right breast. I just feel like it's never going to end - the anxiety of it all! Not a fun feeling!!
Posts.Title: Anyone anxious at end of rads treatment? Stressin67 arnica

Posts.Content: Bendcoles wrote: My sister-in-law actually told me to keep my head up and think the best about this because "who wants to die twice?" WTF? Is this really what I wanted to hear? Being newly diagnosed is bad enough. Trying to figure out all these new words is bad enough. Deciding the best course after the biopsy and MRI is bad enough. But to hear from someone who is supposed to support you that you don't need to die twice - well, I'm speechless as to what to say to her now! Why can't people just let you know how much they care about you and that they're there for you ... to support you and pray for you? Why the stupid comments? Diane diagnosed w/IDC and DCIS biopsy on 6/1, MRI on 6/11, surgery on 6/18 Diane, cancerous calcifications 6/18, 33 radiation done! Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: The comments Bendcoles WendyInCalif
A Letter To My Doctors Bendcoles marie5890

Posts.Content: Bendcoles wrote: I plan on sending this to my GYN, surgeon, rad oncologist and oncologist. ~ Diane TO WHOM IT MAY CONCERN: My name is Diane Cole and I am 48. I am a daughter, sister, aunt, cousin, sister-in-law, wife and mother. I teach preschool Sunday school, work part time at my church and do daycare in my home. Why am I telling you this? Because to you I am just a patient or a case number. To some I am a car or house payment. I have survived my husband�s infidelity and the birth of our 2 children by c-section. I have had to talk to doctors about a heart murmur, spina bifida, hydrocephalus, chiari malformation of the brain, hip dyplasia and seizures as well as things like leg braces and wheelchairs. This past month I have had a follow up mammogram, talked to my gynecologist about microcalcifications seen on that mammogram, let a surgeon I just met cut into my left breast to do a stereotactic biopsy, gotten a diagnosis of ductal carcinoma in situ and invasive ductal carcinoma, had an MRI on both breasts, had an ultrasound on both breasts and had surgery for a lumpectomy and a sentinel lymph node biopsy. I have had to look up words I�ve never heard before online. I have talked to my surgeon, gynecologist, a radiologist, an oncology radiologist, someone from the Sara Fisher breast cancer organization and an oncologist. I have waited in rooms half naked so someone can come in and inspect my breasts. I have waited in the oncologist�s exam room for almost an hour without anyone coming in to let me know he is running behind! I have had to tell that oncologist that I don�t appreciate being treated in such a manner because it lets me know I am not respected. Common courtesy is something his office needs to learn. I have accepted his apology. I have heard that some of my tests have come back and others have not. I have learned to play the waiting game. It�s a game I do not enjoy. I have been told that I have been discussed at something called a breast cancer clinic on Thursday mornings. I hope by them discussing me they learn something to help someone else. I will know soon if I will need radiation with hormonal therapy, chemotherapy or a combination of all or some of these. This journey is one I never signed up for. It is a rollercoaster ride I want to get off of. But here I am � on the ride anyway. Some of you will take this ride with me. Some of you will just hear about the ride. I hope no one else ever has to go on this ride but I know better. So here I am and I hope after reading this you will be a better person on the ride. I hope I will be too. Diane, cancerous calcifications 6/18, 33 radiation done! Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: A Letter To My Doctors Bendcoles marie5890

Posts.Content: Bendcoles wrote: When my daughter was born 15 yrs ago with spina bifida and a lot of other issues I knew God was testing my faith. It's been a long hard road and many times I've lost my faith. Now that I'm going through breast cancer, did my radiation and now am looking at a hysterectomy soon ... I don't know how much more I can take! Have any of you ever felt like this? I know there is a God out there. But when I ask him questions I just don't feel like he's there any more. I don't want to argue with anyone. I was just wondering. Thanks, Diane Diane, cancerous calcifications 6/18, 33 radiation done! Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Has anyone lost their faith? Bendcoles arnica

Posts.Content: Bendcoles wrote: The FISH test was negative which is good. The Oncotype DX number is 15 which is in the low range and with hormone therapy only I'd have a 10% chance of recurrance. All of this means I don't need chemo. I go Friday for my simulation at the cancer center and I'll start radiation after we get back from our Ohio vacation the end of August. Then I'll go on tamoxifen afterward. The waiting is the hard part and I'm glad that part is over, at least for now. Diane biopsy on microcalcifications 6/1, dx of DCIS and IDC 6/4, lumpectomy 6/18 (clear margins and no lymph node involvement) Diane, cancerous calcifications 6/18, 33 radiation done! Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2007 11:41PM Bendcoles wrote: I think in the beginning we all try to put on a brave face. Then reality sets in and we deal with it however is best for each of us. I hope she does visit us here. She will feel the love and support and know she is not alone! ~ Diane

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2007 10:25PM Bendcoles wrote: A huge thank you to all of you! I was struggling with feeling this way. All of your support and prayers are so appreciated! I knew I could come here and find wonderful women who understood! Hugs to you all!
